data.text: How to Fly with Your Bike: Cheapest Option to Pack Your Bicycle

There are regular posts asking about what are the best bike travel box's & bags. The problem is what to do with your expensive box if you'd ideally want to arrive at one location, cycle across some countries then return home from a different location. The cheapest answer is to use the cardboard box's that new bikes are delivered from the factory to the retail shop. My friend Sonya Katharine Brannan has just returned to Scotland after a 4 week tour of Spain. She flew into Alicante, cycled north to the Pyr√©n√©es / Basque country, then flew home from Santander. Cardboard box's were used for both flights Here are photo's of the bikes being built up on arrival at Alicante, then dismantled to fit into the box for the return flight from Santander.

Just wondering how you got the bike boxes to the Scottish airport along with your bikes and paniers? I presume a friend maybe helped out at the Alicante airport end either dropping the boxes off and you cycle to airport to meet friend and boxes. Still trying to pluck up courage to fly with bikes and work out how to do it. We live no where near an airport.
data.author: Ian Barker

data.text: This is my way of doing it when I need to fly.

data.text: , we assembled our bikes at Malaga airport and cycled away from the airport. We left the boxes there. This is a photo of how we got the boxes to Santander airport. We flattened them, rolled them up and cycled.

data.author: Patrick Morris

data.text: Some suggestions: I mostly tour with an SS coupled tandem that fits into two hard shell cases. I have had success shipping them ahead to my destination. Hostels seem really willing to hold them (they always have luggage lockers). However, in Korea, I left them behind in Seoul with my airbnb host (booked on both ends of the trip, so she let them stay there for free). We then biked south to Busan, ferry to Jeju Island. Once done, I went to a bike shop and got two bike boxes and just packed the two tandem halves into the boxes for the one hour flight back to Seoul. Once there, they were packed into the cases for the flight back to the US.
data.author: Charles E. Hansberry

data.text: Free bike box from local bike shop, throw it in trash when you arrive, when you return use another cardboard box. Don't use cardboard for super lightweight bikes that can't take the rough handling by the airport.
data.author: Clyde Slade

data.text: Cardboard boxes are not practical. The best solution for me is bubble wrap foil. Upcycled if possible.
data.author: Jan Brelih

data.text: If cardboard bike box's are used by every bike manufacturer to deliver new bikes half way round the World to the retail bike shop - then they are strong enough to easily survive a single flight with a tourer's bike in it. I also pack my clothes, towels etc into plastic bags then pack them in with the bike in the box. This gives both added protection for the bike and saves me the cost of paying for hold luggage !
data.author: Tam Noon

data.text: I attach clothes or anything on a bike frame with straps. You cannot really bring cardboard box on your bicycle when cycling to the airport.
data.author: Jan Brelih

data.text: I successfully used a bag made of heavy duty construction poly when I went to Iceland.
data.author: Clive Cuttler
Jeff Stone

data.text: And this was cool with the airline?
data.author: Emily Scherer

data.text: Absolutely. I flew with Iceland Air and when I checked recently, it is still an acceptable way to ship a bike. I stuffed my panniers into a light weight duffel bag and checked it in. My front handlebar bag has a carrying strap so I brought that on the plane with me.
data.author: Clive Cuttler

data.text: I used a queen sized mattress bag. Folded it and carried it on the rear rack
data.author: Jeff Stone

data.text: this picture looks like you wrapped your panniers as well? Is that correct?
data.author: Mary Ervin Pinizzotto

data.text: I got a similar heavy duty clear plastic bike bag from Wiggle when I flew to Gran Canaria last month. Put pipe lagging over all the frame tubes and copious amounts of big bubble wrap. Did the usual deflating the trees, removing pedals and turning handle bars but EasyJet REFUSED to accept my bike at check in Luton. I was laughed at. Numerous of their staff came by to gawp and make snide and rude remarks about my packing despite m bike probably being more safe than in a box. I had printed out their bike packaging policy which states various ways of packing your bike including a bicycle bag but they weren't having any of it. They told me I needed a hard bike case like the Pro cyclists use. I told them I wasn't a Pro cyclist, yet and in any case their written policy did not state this. Then one their staff laughed at me. they then told me I needed to get my bike wrapped but their bike policy does not state this either. In any case I eventually found the wrapping place having struggled with my bike and luggage up and down what concourse at Luton several times. The wrapping place is only open in the mornings. It was 2:30pm. But they would have know this. It was humiliating and demeaning. They were taking the piss. I wasn't able to board my flight and missed it. Easy Jet are a shit airline. So I demanded to see their duty manager who eventually booked me on another flight from Gatwick 2 days later which was a real PITA to get to. The airline ground staff just made things up as they went along refusing to follow their written bike packing policy as given on their website and I had in my hand. One particular officious and nasty woman from EJ said "I've been working here 13 years and never seen a bike packed like that and laughed" "Well you have now!" I've flown with my bike packaged just like this quite a few times without incident, no damage whatsoever and with EJ! They were just b*****ds. So two days later I went down to Gatwick with my Brompton. No issues with this but it was total chaos there. My advice is never fly EJ with a bike as it was a nightmare. EJ refused to refund me all the expenses I incurred getting home and then back out to Gatwick two days later, refused to refund me the ¬£90 I had paid to carry my full frame bike as the Brompton packaged up can passed as checked hold luggage. They claimed my Brompton weighed 31kgs, as if, and was over sized which it was not in a Dimpa bag and heavy duty BDH Brompton fabric bag. It weighed 18.3kgs with the external bags, tools etc inside. EJ are just w*****rs. If you take your bike in a clear heavy duty plastic bike bag like this they will refuse to allow you to even check in let alone board your flight despite it being fine according to their own bike carriage and packing policy. So now I have to sue EJ to try to get my money back. I also lost 3 days of my holiday and couldn't do the off road riding I had wanted to do on Gran Canaria with my full sized frame bike as although the Brompton is good it is not for off road trail riding. I had to radically change what I had planned and paid for. Lost two nights of hotel accommodation as well. I have flown lots long haul with my bikes in these plastic clear heavy duty bags with no problems whatsoever.
data.author: Alex Maudorn

data.text: the clerks at the United Desk in Amsterdam gave me the same line until I showed them their policy (which I printed out) they didn‚Äôt know that you could use a bag. The supervisor walked by and again tried to tell me it had to be cardboard, I showed her the written policy, she made me sign a liability waver for damage (that was in the policy also). Each airline is different

data.text: I think the issue might be with airports who do the baggage handling. Our polythene wrapped tandem has been accepted successfully by EasyJet in Gatwick for the last 10/15 years. We also flew with Ryanair from Fez, successfully, only to be refused by Ryanair in Stansted (eventually paid ¬£13 to have it shrink wrapped and it was accepted) Geneva INSISTS on cardboard boxes and I understand now. When we flew Gatwick - Geneva (polythened) the tandem arrived mangled. I think it has to do with each airport handling the baggage differently

data.text: That is exactly what did - she cycled to a bike shop close to the airport, where she obtained some box's, rolled them up to fit on their panniers then cycled to the airport, where the bikes were part dismantled, and fitted into the box for the flight home.

data.text: , indeed. We have also done exactly that, many times.

data.text: I've done it dozens of times. The important consideration is to always schedule at least two days at your destination so you have time to find and aquire a box.

data.text: we had 2 flights. The 1st we took a taxi and let our boxes to the hostel where we spent the first nights so we found them after one month. For the 2nd flight we didn't ee te boxes anymore so we unpacked the bikes at the airport (guards didn't reammt enjoy it...)

data.text: Just hire a taxi van. The rear seats usually fold down or you can lay the box over the rear seat. I have done it many times.
data.author: Kerry Vanderzalm

data.text: thank you. You take your bikes out of the box then put them in or you take the bikes out of the boxes? I'm transporting 2 bikes, plus my burley trailer that folds down, plus 2 large luggages and theres 4 of us. Do u think that would work? And you slide your bikes
data.author: Diana Guzman

data.text: as Kerry wrote, it fit in a taxi van.
data.author: R√©mi Valln

data.text: On most trips I simply take a taxi van to a hotel with the bike still in box and assemble the bike in the hotel room over a few cold beers. On some trips I just put the bike back together right there at the airport and ride away from there. Last month I landed in Redding, California late at night and there were no taxi vans available. so I had to assemble my bike at the airport and then ride 30 km in the darkness to my hotel. In the end it's all part of the adventure üòâ I always contact a bike shop well ahead of time near the last city on my route so I know they will have box reserved for me. I always offer to pay for a box but they usually just give one to me.
data.author: Kerry Vanderzalm

data.text: great tips! Thanks so much for the specific details. This particular adventure requires alot of details be worked out since I'm traveling with kiddos, but alot of your details really help. üëç
data.author: Diana Guzman

data.text: I've never traveled by bike with kids along. You are brave! I think you should hire a van in advance of your arrival to guarantee that you have a van large enough to carry the bikes and the kids all together.

data.text: I love Portugal! I'm from Vancouver, Canada and will be riding in Portugal in September, from Lisbon to Santiago de Compostela, Spain. I was also riding in Portugal in 2017. On that trip we went from Lisbon to Seville, Spain to Gibraltar to Sagres, Portugal. I am 1/2 Portuguese on my mother's side.

data.text: that's so great to hear! Portugal really has everything in it's richly beautiful little country; the people, the food and the cycling. data.text: I stopped trying to find bike boxes a long time ago and got a Bike Friday. It folds into the suitcase/trailer and the suitcase is a standard size and checks in with no extra cost. I've flown and biked all over the world with this bike. I've tried a lot of different travel/touring options (boxes, soft bags, S&S) and this is by far my favorite and what has worked best for me.

data.text:
Bike Friday's New World Tourist that you can get with the travel case and trailer setup: https://bikefriday.com/product/bike-friday-new-world-tourist-folding-bike Bike Partners also sells the travel case and trailer setup separately: https://www.bikepartners.net/bike-friday-travel-case-packing-system-samsonite-s.html Depending on what part of the world you're in, there are other partners that sell Bike Friday's products. You can contact Bike Friday to see if there's someone in your area.

data.author: Justin Scholz

data.text: We then use a recycling bin if available, or cut the boxes into pieces and put into trash cans. On this particular occasion, a maintenance vehicle came along and offered to take the boxes away when we were finished with them.
data.author: Justin Scholz

data.text: Cardboard box:I use half a plastic bottle under the front fork and cable ties to secure the parts (pedals, front wheel and the rest) inside the cardboard box. Fill up with clothes/plastic bubble. Also tape half a plastic bottle on one corner of the box to drag the box short distances in the airport when/before wagons are not available.

data.text: Always carry a 15mm pedal wrench. For me to pack my bike, removing the wheel, seat post, front rack and handlebars+stem takes about 15 mins and a couple of hex keys. That's the beauty of the Kona Sutra!
